Title: American Sniper - Official Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Im gonna be honest I found this movie quite overrated. Before anyone starts hating on me I have to say this: I respect Chris Kyle and everyone serving in our military.

Now taking politics/social beliefs out of the equation and looking at it just from a movie perspective, there really wasn't anything special about this movie and I actually found it kind of dull. It was just a basic war movie with no stand out features. I wouldn't want to watch it again. Now I'm not saying it's a bad movie but it is not as good as people say it is, hence me finding it overrated. I am really happy Birdman beat it for Best Picture. I only saw three of the eight movies nominated (Birdman, Grand Budapest Hotel, American Sniper) and this was my least favorite. Birdman had much better acting, cinematography, plot, script, music, etc. Now American Sniper did make more money at the box office, but it's quality over quantity. If it was based on box office money, then we'd have Michael Bay movies winning Best Picture.

I just wanted to express my opinion. I'd like to hear what people have to say so feel free to respond. I'm happy to listen.

Comment:
Normally A sniper is not used for offensive operations, Snipers are used for occupation and rarely Â tactical defense..

In ww2 Snipers were considered cowards by the enlisted men. Mainly due to the fact that they killed soldiers when they were hanging up laundry or playing cards or just walking to the latrine. this was after the soldier had survived a ferocious battle only to be killed doing routine life necessities You have to realize there were millions of deaths from "drafted" men in all countries just in conventional battle sometimes hand to hand, they really looked down on sniping. A sniper back then had few Â friends among Â the enlisted man and little quarter shown to him by the enemy.

Little has changed over the years for sniping use. most snipers kill other soldiers while they are in transit not battle, since a live battle is fluid snipers have no time to set up a prepared position.

Snipers harass a enemy who has taken control "after" they won the battle or they harass a defeated enemy when Â your side has taken control "after" a battle..but the battle itself snipers are rarely used.

it's easy to rack up kills sitting on a population under occupation or a army settling down in a city and soldiers going about daily life requirements.. quite hard to do so in the heat of battle

Title: American Sniper - Official Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I went to watch Clint Eastwood's American Sniper the other day. See I'm quite redpilled on american imperialism, and their oppression of most of the nations in the third world, but the movie surprised me.

I marveled at Cooper's perfect performance, and was struck with awe by the movie's (previously unseen) story, the story of he that is a WORKING MAN and a SHEEPDOG, a protector of the innocent, blessed by G-d with the gift of aggressiveness, and with the grace to perform and protect.

Then it happened, the ending. I felt a strange sensation as the hardened war veteran that is Cooper walked his (unbeknownst to me then, but his last) steps to the man he sought to help, to overcome.

When the screen faded to black and that heartbreaking text filled the screen, I couldn't help but cry. I stood up and started applauding. The whole crowd at the cinema stood up and clapped, clapped for He that was a hero, willing to protect us, foreigners (I'm chilean) against a terrible threat. I clapped heartily, and we all chanted the American National Anthem. We pledged to the flag and golden bald eagles came flying carrying a giant american flag which was shown to all of us.

That day I understood America's superiority and how wrong I have been my entire life. I dropped my communist college and decided to become a proud working man and sheepdog.

God bless America, God bless Chris Kyle and God bless you, mister Eastwood, wherever you may be.

"MEDIA SHILL"

Are you guys serious? It's a movie directed by Clint Eastwood. Of COURSE it's going to be about America, and of COURSE it's going to challenge modern ideals about America.Â 

It wouldn't be a Clint Eastwood movie if it didn't.

Look, I haven't seen the movie, so I can't say much, but what I will say is that it looks like a very dramatic piece, with a lot of tension and character development and action and thought.

That's it.

It's not some sort of "COD inspired," "American piece of shit propaganda." Many who are praising the film say the movie is about him, not about the politics of the Iraq war. â€œItâ€™s a movie about a man, a character study,â€ said lead actor Bradley Cooper. â€œThe hope is that you can somehow have your eyes opened to the struggle of a soldier, as opposed to the specificity of the war.â€ Others argue American Sniper is â€œboth a tribute to the warrior and a lament for war,â€ as the Associated Press reviewer wrote.

BS . Regardless of the intentions of those making these claims, BS.

This is a profoundly reactionary movie. American Sniper humanizes and glorifies Chris Kyle, an unrepentant Christian fundamentalist mass murderer who killed 160 Iraqis (supposedly the most â€œkillsâ€ by any U.S. soldier in history). Meanwhile, the movie demonizes and dehumanizes every single Iraqi (with the possible exception of one family), portraying them as evil terrorists and â€œsavagesâ€ who deserve to die.

By telling this story through Kyleâ€™s eyes and purported experience (and prettifying that story), American Sniper weaves a fable about the U.S. invasion of Iraq and its role in the world: America is a force for good. Whatever its mistakes, the U.S. sends its military to places like Iraq to try to protect the innocent and destroy evil. Title: American Sniper - Official Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Are you ready for a reality change in military war?

Once again Clint Eastwood proves his mastery of the art of filmmaking with American sniper. In an entertaining way you are provoked to transcend your preconceived mindset and the conventional wisdom. While the movie has reignited American public debates about the virtue and value of the conflict in the Middle East, it is the internal moral conflict confronting the American sniper that captivated me the most.Â  As you weigh the decisions, your mindset is revealed and your heart is challenged. For me this reality change is what a great film is all about. I love its great camera work and atmosphere but it is the emotional power and depth of the story which makes it a classic.
This film closely captures the mood, so you really felt present during the latest Iraq conflict and the everyday rebellion and insurgency combat in the streets. Only the US soldiers wear uniforms, they can be surprised and attacked from any quarter and by any man, woman and child. The action is close and personal so that it hits the heart of the viewer. The term non-military age man, seems to mean a child of 6 or 7 years, who proved unable to hold an anti-tank rocket launcher and fire it at a US vehicle 20 meters away. Chris, a crack American sniper watches every second through his gun sights, deliberating whether he should wait a little longer, or to fire now.Â  When US troops use force in house to house searches, they are confronted face to face with Iraqâ€™s families at home. Children, babies, women and military age men are terrorized by American soldiers in their search for one Muslim terrorist. As a Muslim sniper starts shooting US soldiers, it seems that he is acting in the same way as the American snipers.Â  The films shows how both sides are brought closely together. Could it be that they are becoming almost indistinguishable?
The moral conflict in Chrisâ€™s mind and heart threatened to tear him to pieces and also his family on his return to the USA. Â Yet he declared to his psychologist that his 160 kills was well justified in his efforts to serve his country and save his brothers in arms.Â  In his thirst to kill, Chris has lost his moral war without realizing it.Â  Eastwood carefully sequences the scenes of heroism and of moral corruptions to provoke viewers to evaluate the true meaning of heroism and war.Â  The â€˜just warâ€™ waged by the US has turned the very people, the ordinary citizens of Iraqi, it is trying to rescue (from terrorism) into its enemies.Â  The US may have captured the land, but it lost the hearts and minds of the people in the land.
For the perceptive one, this film dramatically also shows that those involved in military war are presented with the moral conflict more intensely than in nearly any other situation.
I watched the movie in California with two American Vietnam veterans on each side of me. The film ended and there was an intense and heavy silence in the whole cinema. If the goal was that to shock the audience to a deeper reflection, then this film is masterful.
Could this film have unveiled the reality of â€œjustâ€ military wars?
One of the veterans told me, what he had probably hid for years, that this was also his experience of Vietnam. The other reeling emotionally, said â€œI canâ€™t talk about it, I have to get home quickly. It brought too many memories back.â€
The war in Vietnam finally ended as the American public rebelled, when confronted with the terrible realities on TV in the comfort of their homes. Personally I think that #Clint Eastwood will prove to be the real hero who has reignited the public debate on the moral of the modern American wars with this film.
The next day working at Playford Games, I felt a change inside. I design the Moral Conflict games to encourage players, to weigh their hearts and their actions. My illustrator in Germany and I have been mulling over our latest title picture, where we portray the agony of the 1945 moral conflict within the soldiers, children and women in the streets of Berlin.Â  After seeing Clint Eastwoodâ€™s work, I am inspired to make this picture count and reach the hearts and minds of as many as possible.

Comment: Apparently people are misinterpreting this. I have not seen the movie yet, but from what I can tell from this trailer it's an anti-war film. It's not glorifying the war. It's supposed to show the ugly side, where soldiers are expected to use their own judgment to make a decision that nobody else can make and regardless of their own moral values. Unlike most soldiers, the sniper sees their targets clearly. They have to watch them and think carefully about their intentions. This movie is exploring the fact that these soldiers are NOT merely weapons. They are HUMANS and they make mistakes just like any other person. Except most people never have to carry the weight of murdering another human, regardless of who they are. This movie is supposed to help you realize that there is good and evil on both sides of a conflict. And that sometimes the line between you, your enemies and your allies is not so clear.

Wow. Â So many idiots in the comments assuming this is some sort of pro-war, pro-America propaganda. Â Did they not even watch the trailer??? Â It is showing how war is devastating, not only to the country it happens to, but to all the soldiers who survive and go home!Â 

It's somehow "propaganda" for showing that soldiers are humans? Â That soldiers DON'T want to kill people unless they absolutely MUST?
You think that sniper was thrilled he had to kill a young boy? Â He would have shot him right away if he was. Â But he hesitated because he thought of his own son, his own family. Â He hesitated because he's a human being, and knows the value of another human being.

If he hadn't shot the boy, his comrades would have died. Â Those soldiers also have families. Â Those soldiers are also fathers and mothers. Â You think it would have been better for him to let that boy live, and those men die? Â That their families suffer over the loss of their loved ones, that their children never see them again, that their spouses suffer from grief and depression?

Sometimes the lives of the many outweigh the lives of the few. Â It's not a nice reality, but it IS a reality. Â I'm sorry, but the world is just not a pretty place. Â This movie is realistic. Â It's not propaganda. Â Deal with it.

Title: American Sniper - Official Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The story behind the Craft Skull logo combines several meaningful pieces of our founder's life and service to this great nation, but mainly honors his fallen teammates. As part of SEAL Team 3, he and his fellow teammates painted similar skulls on their gear in order to strike fear in the enemy. The crosshair symbolizes his time spent on a sniper rifle and is also in the form of a templar cross to symbolize his faith. Lastly, the crosshair is on the right eye to honor SO2 Ryan Job USN (SEAL), who was critically wounded when he was shot in the right eye while on deployment to Iraq in 2006.
Following the successful rescue mission by Navy SEALs of freighter Captain Richard Phillips on Easter morning, 2009, Ryan Job was asked by a local reporter if he thought using Navy SEALs against Somali pirates was overkill. His response was, "despite what your mamma told you, violence does solve problems." Ryan Job died in September of that year following complications during reconstructive surgery.The Craft Skull is a daily reminder to us all the sacrifices brave warriors have made and what it takes to triumph over evil.

Combine that with the left wing public school system, and the 'propaganda' is actually significantly more liberal/anti gun then it is right wing/pro gun in North America.Â 

Now, I obviously think it's fair to question the legitimacy of America's purpose/goals whenever they go to war. However, I do find it mind-blowing how people act like America does everything for completely selfish reasons and that they don't care at all about the civilians in those areas. If they didn't care at all, why would they risk using ground troops when they could just level whole cities with bombs? Why would they spend tons on aid money and attempting to help police and establish governments long after they have eliminated/scattered their targets? Furthermore, it's not like Iraq and Afghanistan were perfectly happy areas of the world before the U.S. decided to invade -> Do you honestly think that the Taliban weren't worth opposing?

If you really support women's rights, freedom of religion, basic human rights, etc., then how can you refuse to intervene/fight for these things when a dictator/terrorist group decides they aren't going to adhere to these rules? Â How can we see children getting beheaded, women getting set on fire, etc. and just say 'well, it's their country, so we have no right to intervene'? How can a European wag their finger at the U.S. for being 'idiots' when they have recently been losing the battle to keep Islamic extremism out of their own countries? It seems like Europe has immediately slid right back into the apathetic mindset that they were in prior to World War 2 -> Seriously Europe, grow a spine! If passive aggressive groups are trying to push Sharia law on you in your own countries or if groups of people in middle-eastern nations are slaughtering innocent people, DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT. I'd rather have a country like the U.S. around that is at least trying to make a positive difference, than a bunch of countries that like to pretend that they are intellectually superior, but are completely unwilling to actually DO anything.Â

Comment:
It would be comical how so many making comments here are so clueless to the reality of the world but for the fact they can influence others. Until you have walked in another country and watched the horrors of this world unfold, your opinion will always lack substance. You can call me names or say that's not fair or whatever other pointless response but that is the simple truth. 
I joined the Navy at 17, spent my 18th birthday in Desert Storm. Later I was in Somalia and watched scum take food from starving families to force their sons to serve in their "army". Then we put our boots on their necks and it stopped. Until we left of course. Then it started all over again and our next President didn't handle it very well. Then I was in Serbia. More outstanding people killing, raping and destroying in the name of religion and ethnicity. 
Those are just some of my experiences which are nothing compared to the guys of the last 13 years. Or men like my grandfather who was at Omaha beach.
If you haven't been to another country, much less one at war, you simply don't have an opinion that matters to me. You are of course entitled to your opinion, that's a freedom men like me protect. But don't for an instant think it matters to someone who has experienced the reality of this world.  
Our government does plenty of things I'm not happy about, regardless of who's in charge. But history will show what we really are. Flawed yes. But we are the only thing standing between humanity and total darkness. What if Hitler and Tojo had won? Or if Stalin had his way after that? We are where we are because other nations failed to stop those men and it fell to us. And every action since goes back to that War. Everything we face today somehow is related. Go educate yourself and then at least we can talk.

Comment: Wow. Im guessing that 95% of the people who have been commenting have either no common sense or have the intelligence of a 3 year old. First off, some people are desperate and will do anything to support a cause, even if it will lead to death, which is exactly what Chris Kyle did. He supported his country, and he was willing to do it even if death was the result. I have read the book, and even though he did shoot the civilian it was the ONLY time he did shoot towards one, and his motives made sense. He did it to support and protect his fellow comrades, and if what he did "was truly a crime" he would have been charged with murder and sent to prison. Every confirmed kill is recorded, filed and reviewed by each branch of the military. Another thing that pissed me off is that there are hundreds of articles about Chris Kyle and his dedication to his country, and his autobiography, (Which states ALL true information, confirmed the the SEALs and editors themselves.) So before you start to spread complete crap, try and research first. But most off all, the most infuriating statement was that americans are 'obsessed with killing and the military and kill without reason'. No. Not at all. Without our soldiers and army, we would've been decimated a long time ago. Do you think that we should just sit back, and let other countries just attack and kill hundreds of thousands of innocent people? No. Thats exactly why we have the military. First off, you have to volunteer to join and, those who join have to patriotic, and must be willing to give up their life in order to save hundreds. Of course its in our everyday lives, its in everyone else's as well. Its everywhere. We have people like Chris Kyle to help prevent major chaos from spreading. People who have been commenting negative things need to stop. Get some common sense and realise that this happens everywhere, its not just americans who have guns and weaponry. I respect Chris Kyle for the sacrifices he made for America, as well as everyone else who has joined the military to help their country. So everyone who has been negative needs to calm down and figure out how wrong they really are. Because not only are you being unpatriotic, you have been insulting other people. Keep your comments to yourself, people don't want to hear your jabs at heros who have save lives.

Comment:
This dude, Chris Kyle, performed what I consider to be a necessary function.
I do wonder, however, at how different perspectives define a person. In any other walk of life, Kyle would be considered a mass murderer (which he is). However, because it is an act of war rather than an event happening near where we live, we dont think of him as that.
Before you start to flame, understand that I actually have no issue with Kyle, nor his kill count. Like I say, I feel he performed a necessary function.
I do think the distinction in how we perceive the act of killing based on the setting is an interesting study though.

Title: American Sniper - Official Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Try to keep something in mind people, that perhaps you've forgotten or simply don't appreciate as you post your comments and in some cases, detracting remarks...this entire exchange of dialog from first comment to last is a perfect example of 'Freedom of Speech'.
That's merely a dream or a vague concept to some unfortunate souls in this world but, it is your RIGHT as an American citizen. Â A GIFT that was earned FOR you; left for you; and continues to this day to be secured for you by men and women out there who go nameless for the most part. Â If it isn't hard enough to endure wondering what might happen to them, many of them have families of their own at home who depend on them simply SURVIVING what they HAVE to do, adding to their burden. Â  Â  Â  Â 
I am 48 years old. Â  Â  Â  Â  I was born and raised in this country. Â  Â  Â  Â I have a wife and two children. Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â I can say without hesitation that I have indeed enjoyed or have at the least had the opportunity to enjoy that which America offers. Â  Â 
In short...I have taken,but....I have NEVER served. Â I am regretful of that and I ashamed of that as well. Â Furthermore, I find that that regret and shame grows little by little with each passing year of my life and quickened all the more each time I see headlines about whichever conflict our service men and women are now engaged in or committed to. Â I CAN not, DO not want to imagine the stress and anxiety that any one of them must carry each and every moment of their existence while deployed so that we can enjoy the luxury....the entertainment of playing 'Monday Morning Quarterbacks'. Â Second guessing a man's decision without even being able to fathom the experience.

In retrospect, I suppose he could have simply shot the woman as soon as he saw the weapon. Â He could have shot her immediately after she handed it to the boy and having done so perhaps the boy having witnessed this would have lost his nerve....perhaps....could have....should have. Â Then again, I've now had at least 20 mins or more to to consider my many many options and their possible outcomes. Â Chris Kyle had MOMENTS ONLY to, quite literally. make a 'Life or Death' decision for....How many people?

Honestly folks I was just flipping through movie trailers when I came upon this discussion. Â I really don't know anything about Chris Kyle but it seems likely to me that by the time this 'Hypothetical' was presented to HIM he had probably already seen 'first hand' the horrific consequences of such a situation if it is permitted to play out to it's conceived ending. Â This is an all too familiar fanatically extreme tactic of theirs and to try and understand it...is pointless. Â As I said before, I have never served and I simply don't know if I would be able to pull the trigger, or at least without enough hesitation for it to have not been too late, but, I can not imagine that shooting a child, BELIEVED to be an enemy combatant, whether right or wrong, is even close to being the ugliest that WAR has to offer. Â So, if you still insist on putting Chris Kyle and other American Service men and women on trial for such occurrences then I will offer my own opinion for you to consider...

It is not for me to say whether this was right or wrong, I will NOT judge this man or any like him in the same situation. Â I simply don't feel that I've earned that RIGHT. Â I can, however, at least try to understand THIS man and empathize with HIS predicament, at least a little. Â Conversely though, I am absolutely certain that if I were to live to be 98 or 198 for that matter, I will never... EVER...understand or be able to accept a Man or a Woman who willingly hands an explosive device to a small BOY, (an innocent), and directs him toward, what THEY know to be, his certain death as a tactical maneuver while they watch and observe from a strategic position of safety. Â Playing on their enemy's Sense of Decency, (that THEY perceive as a weakness which will cause them to hesitate), they calculate, they hope, and even expect he'll survive just long enough and get just close enough to inflict the maximum amount of damage. Â  Â  Â 
I sincerely hope that this child did NOT fully understand the finality of what was about to happen to him because if he did...and he WAS Â 'on board' for it,...if he were actually that dedicated to this act we're discussing, owing to the way that he had been conditioned from birth...then none of us...will EVER...see a peaceful end to this conflict in our life time. Â  Â 

War represents the ultimate degradation of humanity in my humble opinion but when the two opposing factions are equally set in their resolve and so far from understanding one another as even human beings, history has shown us that it is far too often unavoidable and even necessary and whether your doing it for your "Country" or for your "God"...what does it really matter?

My point is this,
You have a right to an opinion about this, no matter what that may be. Â By all means, exercise it, I say. Â However, that right was won for us all by those who preceded us with absolutely NO guarantee on it's longevity or even it's continued existence beyond their own. Â They secured it for us...and then they left it to US to preserve for the next generation. Â If you're not happy with the Government and their policies, foreign or domestic, then you NEED to speak out. Â That's how it works. Â That's how it's supposed to work anyway. Â Maintain a clear distinction though,....that's Politics not people. Â The soldiers portrayed by actors in the film clips are people. Â We don't know who the Boy was, but we also don't know the names of the group of soldiers Chris Kyle is covering. Â Perhaps one of them was a relative of yours, your co worker's or neighbor's Son, a former classmate or friend of your Son or Daughter or even yours. Â Don't post disrespectful comments about them. Â Don't vilify them, or condemn them for their role in this mess. Â They don't deserve that. Â At 48 years of age I can tell you that I have been subjected to this my entire life. Â As far back as I can remember I'd heard the "latest reports" while my parents watched '60 Minutes' every Sunday night and the never ending on again off again "Peace Talks" throughout every decade since. Â This is in the nature of Mankind and so it has been since the dawn of time. Â These kids are just the latest participants. Â Different players, little bit different Politics, but, in the end... the same old game played out to the same conclusion...nobody really wins. Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â
